title: Ticket #5779: the MapFile class needs to handle literal keys
description:
in support of #5751, if the usermap has hundreds or thousands of entries in the mapfile, the current MapFile class is fairly slow to do lookups in that case. Then the mapfile has keys that are essentially literals (i.e. not making using the regex substitution), we can do much better by implementing that as a hash lookup.

So the MapFile class needs to be able to read input files and treat the second value each row of the file as either a regex or a simple literal key. It would store regex entries in the same way as before, but consecutive simple literal entries of the same method will be coalesced into a single hashtable.

The MapFile class will take a flag to the function that parses a file that tells it whether this new method of parsing is available. If it is, and the second value in a row begins and ends with / (i.e. like a perl regex) then it will be treated as a regex entry. otherwise it will be treated as a simple literal entry.

Regex entries can have one or more letters following the closing / to indicate regex options. The options are

  • i case insensitive
  • U ungreedy

Awk style substitutions will be made on the value of the third field when it is returned. \0 will be substituted for the entire match, \1 for the first regex capture group, etc.

When the second field is not a regex, only \0 will be substituted.

so for example 

mapfile fragment
*   Bob   security,csuser.\0
*   Alice security,math
*   /^todd.*/i htcondor,chtc,csuser.\0
*   /(*.).cs/ csuser.\1
*   /*./  guest

If the above map file is used, the following lookups would occur.

Input Map result
Bob security,csuser.Bob
john guest
ToddL htcondor,chtc,csuser.ToddL
alice.cs.wisc.edu csuser.alice
